NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
OFFICE OF THE REGIONAL DIRECTOR
April 20, 1961
Mr. William G. Harley
President, NAEB
1346 Connecticut Avenue N.W.
Washington 6, D.C.
Dear Bill:
I have refrained from attempting word or line changes to the
proposed letter of agreement with the NETRC for two reasons.
First, I feel you who are "on the ground" and working actively
with the problems are in a position to do the best job. Second,
I doubt that such a document as this can successfully be contrived
by a committee as scattered as our board is between its meetings.
However, in advance of the Columbus meeting I would like to
put some thoughts on paper as background to the deliberations. I
don’t do this with any feeling that I am instructing or preaching
to you or any of our board members. Instead, I hope that clarifi¬
cation of points on which I might be in error will serve construct¬
ively to dispel any misinterpretations I may have of our present
position.
In the first place, I don't think any reasonable person can
doubt that certain agreements must be made between the NETRC and
the NAEB. I won't waste time in belaboring the obvious necessity
of these agreements. Further, we should all realize that agree¬
ments will be made as questions arise in the day-to-day conduct
of the business of the two organizations. Our only choice is
whether these agreements are formal and between organizations, or
informal and between the working presidents and their staffs.
It is my feeling that the main obstacle to constructive agree¬
ments between organizations at this point is a widespread distrust
of the NETRC within NAEB. This distrust runs the scale from mile
uneasiness to the concept of the NETRC as a "monolithic evil" - and
those who hold the most extreme view are not without a good deal
of company.
This NAEB feeling most often finds expression in such phrases
as "I don't trust Jack White." White has become synonymous with
the Center and, as the highest Center official known to the major¬
ity of NAEB members, he has personally been the target for NAEB
members' uneasiness with the Center.
